net.sf.mmm.client.ui.base.widget

Class AbstractUiWidget<VALUE>

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.sf.mmm.client.ui.base.feature.AbstractUiFeatureValueAndValidation<VALUE>
      • net.sf.mmm.client.ui.base.widget.AbstractUiWidget<VALUE>
  • Type Parameters:
    VALUE - is the generic type of the value.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    AttributeReadAriaRole, AttributeReadEnabled, AttributeReadHtmlId, AttributeReadMode, AttributeReadModeFixed, AttributeReadModified, AttributeReadPrimaryStyle, AttributeReadStyles, AttributeReadStylesAdvanced, AttributeReadTooltip, AttributeReadValueAdvanced<VALUE>, AttributeReadVisible, AttributeReadVisibleRecursive, AttributeWriteEnabled, AttributeWriteHtmlId, AttributeWriteMode, AttributeWriteModeFixed, AttributeWriteModified, AttributeWriteOnlyFocused, AttributeWritePrimaryStyle, AttributeWriteStyles, AttributeWriteStylesAdvanced, AttributeWriteTooltip, AttributeWriteValueAdvanced<VALUE>, AttributeWriteVisible, AttributeWriteVisibleAdvanced, UiFeature, UiFeatureEvent, UiFeatureMessages, UiFeatureMode, UiFeatureValidation<VALUE>, UiFeatureValue<VALUE>, UiFeatureValueAndValidation<VALUE>, UiWidget, UiWidgetAbstractWithValue<VALUE>, AttributeReadDisposed, AttributeReadId<String>, AttributeReadValue<VALUE>, AttributeWriteDisposed, AttributeWriteId<String>, AttributeWriteValue<VALUE>, Accessibility, AbstractValidatableObject, HasValueValidators<VALUE>, ValidatableObject<VALUE>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AbstractUiWidgetNative, UiWidgetCustom

    public abstract class AbstractUiWidget<VALUE>
extends AbstractUiFeatureValueAndValidation<VALUE>
implements UiWidgetAbstractWithValue<VALUE>, AttributeWriteModified, AttributeWriteOnlyFocused
    This is the abstract base implementation of UiWidget. Below this class there are two inheritance hierarchies AbstractUiWidgetNative and UiWidgetCustom. To avoid problems with the lack of multi-inheritance in Java, we already implement UiWidgetWithValue. For subclasses that have no value Void is used for <VALUE>.
    Since:
    1.0.0
    Author:
    Joerg Hohwiller (hohwille at users.sourceforge.net)

      • getValueOrException

        public final VALUE getValueOrException(VALUE template)
                                throws RuntimeException
        This method is like AttributeReadValueAdvanced.getValue() but does NOT catch exceptions while parsing the value from the user input. Additionally it allows to provide a template object that gets populated. This allows advanced features with polymorphism as you can also provide a sub-class of <VALUE>.
        Specified by:
        getValueOrException in interface AttributeReadValueAdvanced<VALUE>
        Overrides:
        getValueOrException in class AbstractUiFeatureValueAndValidation<VALUE>
        Parameters:
        template - is the object where the data is filled in. May also be null - then this method will create a new instance.
        Returns:
        the current value of this widget. May be null if empty. If the value type is String the empty String has to be returned if no value has been entered. In case <VALUE> is a mutable object (java bean) and template is NOT null, this method is supposed to return template.
        Throws:
        RuntimeException - if the entered value is invalid (e.g. paring caused a NumberFormatException).

      • getOriginalValue

        public VALUE getOriginalValue()
        This method gets the last value that has been set. After calling AttributeWriteValueAdvanced.setValue(Object) the value can be modified (by the user in case of a widget). Then calls to AttributeReadValueAdvanced.getValue() will return the current value with its potential modifications (as a new object). This method will ensure to get the value that was set before by the program.
        ATTENTION:
        The original value shall never be modified to avoid undesired side effects. Various features such as AttributeWriteValueAdvanced.resetValue() rely on this fact. Therefore AttributeReadValueAdvanced.getValue() will always return a new instance.
        Specified by:
        getOriginalValue in interface AttributeReadValueAdvanced<VALUE>
        Returns:
        the original value.

      • getRecentValue

        protected VALUE getRecentValue()
        Returns:
        the recent value.

      • getValueDirect

        public VALUE getValueDirect(VALUE template,
                            ValidationState state)
                     throws RuntimeException
        This method is a combination of AttributeReadValueAdvanced.getValueOrException(Object) and AbstractValidatableObject.validate(ValidationState). It allows more efficient implementations as determining and creating the value can be expensive. Saving changes requires validation AND on success getting the value, while already validation requires getting the value. For composite UI objects this effect would reinforce to multiply the number of calls to AttributeReadValueAdvanced.getValueOrException(Object).
        NOTE:
        This method is designed for implementors of composite UI objects. API users should only use UiFeatureValueAndValidation.getValueAndValidate(ValidationState).
        Specified by:
        getValueDirect in interface UiFeatureValueAndValidation<VALUE>
        Parameters:
        template - is the object where the data is filled in. May also be null - then this method will create a new instance.
        state - is the ValidationState. If null the validation will be omitted, otherwise an implicit validation is performed.
        Returns:
        the current value. May be null (esp. if invalid).
        Throws:
        RuntimeException - if state is null no validation is performed and input errors are directly thrown causing a fast fail. Otherwise if validation is performed all RuntimeException are catched and according validation failures are collected and visualized by the UI.

      • doGetValue

        protected VALUE doGetValue(VALUE template,
                           ValidationState state)
        This method is called from the data-binding triggered by API methods such as AbstractUiFeatureValueAndValidation.getValue(). In many cases the data-binding already performs the required work to do. However, here is the place to implemented the custom logic to get the value from the actual widget. The following cases have to be distinguished:
        • For native fields this method has to get the actual value from the underlying native widget (text-box, password-field, etc.).
        • For custom fields this method will be responsible to convert from the delegates value (see UiWidgetCustom.getDelegate()) to the proper value type. E.g. if you want to create a custom widget to edit your own datatype such as CustomerNumber based on a UiWidgetTextField you need to convert from String to CustomerNumber.
        • For custom composite widgets you should use getDataBinding(). UiDataBinding.createAndBind(net.sf.mmm.util.pojo.path.api.TypedProperty) that gives you high-level support and makes your live easy. Then there is no need to override this method.
        • For other cases, especially if <VALUE> is Void, there is nothing to do here.
        The implementation of this method has to correspond with the implementation of doSetValue(Object, boolean) .
        Parameters:
        template - is the object where the data is filled in. May only be null if according to data-binding (e.g. if <VALUE> is an (immutable) Datatype).
        state - is the ValidationState. May be null (if the validation is omitted). Should only be used to propagate to getValueDirect(Object, ValidationState) of children.
        Returns:
        the current value of this widget. May be null if empty. If <VALUE> is String the empty String has to be returned if no value has been entered. In case <VALUE> is a mutable object (java bean) the template is NOT null and is to be returned by this method after the value(s) of this widget have been assigned. For immutable datatypes template will be null and this method has to create a new instance of <VALUE> based on the end-users input in the widget.
        See Also:
        doSetValue(Object, boolean)

      • doSetValue

        protected void doSetValue(VALUE value,
                          boolean forUser)
        This method is called from the data-binding triggered by API methods such as setValue(Object, boolean). In many cases the data-binding already performs the required work to do. However, here is the place to implemented the custom logic to get the value from the actual widget. For details see doGetValue(Object, ValidationState).
        Parameters:
        value - is the value to set. Typically a composite object (e.g. java bean) so its attributes are set to fields (see UiWidgetField).
        forUser - true if called from AbstractUiFeatureValueAndValidation.setValueForUser(Object), false if set from AbstractUiFeatureValueAndValidation.setValue(Object).
        See Also:
        doGetValue(Object, ValidationState)

        setValue in interface AttributeWriteValueAdvanced<VALUE>
        Parameters:
        newValue - is the new value to set.
        forUser - true for the semantics of AttributeWriteValueAdvanced.setValueForUser(Object), false for AttributeWriteValueAdvanced.setValue(Object).

      • isModified

        public boolean isModified()
        This method determines if this object (or more precisely its value) is modified. This means that the object has been modified (via a the user interface) since it's value was programatically set for the last time. Often this is also called dirty. A composite object is also modified if one of its children are modified.
        NOTE:
        If the object's value is changed by the end-user to something else but then changed back to its original value it may still remain modified.
        Specified by:
        isModified in interface AttributeReadModified
        Returns:
        true if this object has been modified, false otherwise (if no changes have been made to this object).
        See Also:
        AttributeReadValueAdvanced.getOriginalValue(), AttributeWriteValueAdvanced.setValueForUser(Object)

      • isModifiedRecursive

        protected boolean isModifiedRecursive()
        Returns:
        true if a child or descendant of this object is modified, false otherwise.

      • setModified

        public void setModified(boolean modified)
        This method sets the modified attribute programatically.
        ATTENTION:
        This interface and this method is NOT intended to be used by API users. The strategy how to determine if something is modified should be an implementation secret (another strategy may be to get the value and check if it is equal to the original value what is however not as robust). Instead methods such as AttributeWriteValueAdvanced.setValueForUser(Object) should be provided for API users.
        Specified by:
        setModified in interface AttributeWriteModified
        Parameters:
        modified - is the new value of AttributeReadModified.isModified().
        See Also:
        AttributeReadModified.isModified()

      • setMode

        public void setMode(UiMode mode)
        This method sets the mode of this object. It will change the object to view or edit mode. This is a recursive operation that will also apply to all descendants of this object. If a fixed mode is set (not null), this method will have no effect and recursive calls will stop at this object.
        Specified by:
        setMode in interface AttributeWriteMode
        Parameters:
        mode - is the new UiMode to set.

      • setMode

        protected abstract void setMode(UiMode mode,
                                boolean programmatic)
        Parameters:
        mode - is the new UiMode to set.
        programmatic - - see UiEvent.isProgrammatic().
        See Also:
        setMode(UiMode)

      • clearMessages

        public void clearMessages()
        This method is clearing all messages. This includes validation failures as well as other messages such as infos, errors, or warnings (e.g. in a message-panel). This is a recursive operation that is propagated to all potential children.
        Specified by:
        clearMessages in interface UiFeatureMessages

      • clearValidity

        protected void clearValidity()
        This method may clear potential state information from previous validations. It clears the validity recursively.
        Overrides:
        clearValidity in class AbstractUiFeatureValueAndValidation<VALUE>

      • validateInteral

        private void validateInteral(ValidationState state,
                             VALUE value)
        This method is called from AbstractUiFeatureValueAndValidation.validate(ValidationState) and performs the actual validation of this object. This method performs the recursive validation of potential children of this widget excluding the validation of this widget itself. A legal implementation of a composite widget needs to call AbstractUiFeatureValueAndValidation.validate(ValidationState) on all child widgets.
        Parameters:
        state - is the ValidationState. Never null.
        value - is the current value of this object that has already be determined.

      • doValidate

        protected void doValidate(ValidationState state,
                          VALUE value)
        This method is called from AbstractUiFeatureValueAndValidation.validate(ValidationState) and performs the actual validation of this object. This method performs the recursive validation of potential children of this widget excluding the validation of this widget itself. A legal implementation of a composite widget needs to call AbstractUiFeatureValueAndValidation.validate(ValidationState) on all child widgets.
        Parameters:
        state - is the ValidationState. Never null.
        value - is the current value of this object that has already be determined.

      • addValidator

        public final void addValidator(ValueValidator<? super VALUE> validator)
        This method adds the given ValueValidator to this object. All ValueValidators are invoked in the same order as they are added by this method. They are invoked no matter if the previous ValueValidators failed or succeeded. You should always design ValueValidators in a robust and reusable way (e.g. a range validator should accept null as valid input so it can be used for both mandatory and optional fields).
        Specified by:
        addValidator in interface HasValueValidators<VALUE>
        Parameters:
        validator - is the ValueValidator to add.

      • getContext

        public final AbstractUiContext getContext()
        This method gets the UiContext. This is the container with central components for the UI and client infrastructure. E.g. it contains the widget-factory that created this UiWidget. It may be used internally in UiWidget implementations as well as externally to create new UiWidgets (typically children).
        Specified by:
        getContext in interface UiWidget
        Returns:
        the UiContext.

      • hasWidgetAdapter

        public abstract boolean hasWidgetAdapter()
        Returns:
        true if the UiWidgetAdapter has already been created. Otherwise false (if getWidgetAdapter() has never been called yet).

      • getWidgetAdapter

        protected abstract UiWidgetAdapter getWidgetAdapter()
        This method gets or creates the UiWidgetAdapter.
        ATTENTION:
        On the first call of this method, the UiWidgetAdapter is created. For the purpose of lazy instantiation this should happen as late as possible. Use hasWidgetAdapter() to prevent unnecessary creation.
        Returns:
        the UiWidgetAdapter.

      • getWidgetAdapter

        public static final UiWidgetAdapter getWidgetAdapter(UiWidget widget)
        This method gives access to getWidgetAdapter().
        ATTENTION:
        This method is only for internal purposes when implementing UiWidgets. It shall never be used by regular users (what also applies for all classes in this base packages).
        Parameters:
        widget - is the widget.
        Returns:
        the widget adapter of the given widget.

      • removeFromParent

        protected abstract void removeFromParent()
        This method removes this widget from its parent. The parent is set to null and the native widget is removed from its parent.

        true if the AbstractUiWidget.EventSender has already been created. Otherwise false (if getEventSender() has never been called yet).

      • getEventSender

        protected final AbstractUiWidget.EventSender getEventSender()
        This method gets the AbstractUiWidget.EventSender. It will be created on the first call.
        Returns:
        the AbstractUiWidget.EventSender.

      • addEventHandler

        public final void addEventHandler(UiHandlerEvent handler)
        This method adds the given UiHandlerEvent to this object.
        Specified by:
        addEventHandler in interface UiFeatureEvent
        Parameters:
        handler - is the UiHandlerEvent to add.

      • removeEventHandler

        public final boolean removeEventHandler(UiHandlerEvent handler)
        This method removes the given UiHandlerEvent from this object.
        Specified by:
        removeEventHandler in interface UiFeatureEvent
        Parameters:
        handler - is the UiHandlerEvent to remove.
        Returns:
        true if the handler has been removed successfully, false if it was NOT registered and nothing has changed.
